clinical_study.brief_title: Association Between Telomere Length and Cardiac Dysfunction
clinical_study.official_title: Association Between Relative Telomere Length and Severity of Cardiac Dysfunction

brief_summary.textblock: Compelling epidemiological evidence indicates that alterations of relative telomere length (RTL) are associated with cardiac dysfunction caused by chemotherapy in children with acute leukemia (AL).The aim of this study was to explore association between RTL content in peripheral blood cells could be used as a risk predictor for severity of cardiac damage.

primary_outcome.time_frame: From date of admission until the date of discharging from hospital, assessed up to 5 days
primary_outcome.description: The ratio of RTL to hemoglobin contents was calculated for each sample from standard curves. After that, the ratio for each sample was normalized to a calibrator DNA in order to standardize between different runs, and then defined as the measurement of relative mtDNA contents.Relative expression of mtDNA were measured in young adults suffered from AL.

arm_group.description: 300 patients were recruited, who have diagnosed with acute leukemia by bone marrow biopsy

intervention.description: Relative telomere length in peripheral blood cell

biospec_descr.textblock: Relative telomere length in peripheral blood cell

study_pop.textblock: A total of 300 eligible acute leukemia patients were anticipated to include in this study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 1. histological confirmed acute leukemia; 2. Preparing for chemotherapy;
Exclusion Criteria:
- 1.history of other malignancy; 2.blood transfusion within one month or prior bone marrow transplantation; 3.patients who reluctant to sign informed consent.
